blocks.name: cnzr
blocks.content: The class of nonzero rings.
blocks.origin: const class cnzr { NzRing }

blocks.name: diff.cnzr.s
diff.cnzr.c
diff.cnzr.w
df-nzr
blocks.content: A nonzero or nontrivial ring is a ring with at least two values, or equivalently where 1 and 0 are different. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 24-Feb-2015.)

blocks.name: isnzr
blocks.content: Property of a nonzero ring. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 24-Feb-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm isnzr(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wb(wcel(c0, cnzr), wa(wcel(c0, crg), wne(c1, c2)))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cur, c0))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(c0g, c0))
} = {
  elrab2(hs0, c0, cnzr, crg, wne(c1, c2), wne(cfv(cur, cv(hs0)), cfv(c0g, cv(hs0))))
  neeq12d(cfv(cur, cv(hs0)), cfv(c0g, cv(hs0)), c1, c2, wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  syl6eqr(cfv(cur, cv(hs0)), c1, cfv(cur, c0), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  fveq2(cv(hs0), c0, cur)
  syl6eqr(cfv(c0g, cv(hs0)), c2, cfv(c0g, c0), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  fveq2(cv(hs0), c0, c0g)
  df-nzr(hs0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(crg)
  diff.hs0.w(wne(c1, c2))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm isnzr(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  ‚ä¢ (c0 ‚àà NzRing ‚Üî(c0 ‚àà Ring ‚àß c1 ‚â† c2))
  ‚ä£ c1 =(1r ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c2 =(0 ` c0)
} = {
  elrab2(hs0, c0, cnzr, crg, c1 ‚â† c2, (1r ` hs0)‚â†(0 ` hs0))
  neeq12d((1r ` hs0), (0 ` hs0), c1, c2, hs0 = c0)
  syl6eqr((1r ` hs0), c1, (1r ` c0), hs0 = c0)
  fveq2(hs0, c0, cur)
  syl6eqr((0 ` hs0), c2, (0 ` c0), hs0 = c0)
  fveq2(hs0, c0, c0g)
  df-nzr(hs0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(crg)
  diff.hs0.w(c1 ‚â† c2)
}

blocks.name: nzrnz
blocks.content: One and zero are different in a nonzero ring. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 24-Feb-2015.)

blocks.name: nzrring
blocks.content: A nonzero ring is a ring. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 24-Feb-2015.)

blocks.name: drngnzr
blocks.content: All division rings are nonzero. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 24-Feb-2015.)

blocks.name: isnzr2
blocks.content: Equivalent characterization of nonzero rings: they have at least two elements. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 24-Feb-2015.)

  3expb(wcel(c0, crg), wcel(cv(hs0), c1), wcel(cv(hs1), c1), wi(wceq(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0)), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(hs1))))

  syl3anc((c0 ‚àà Ring ‚àß(1r ` c0)‚â†(0 ` c0)), ‚àÉ(hs0 ‚àà c1, ‚àÉ(hs1 ‚àà c1, ¬¨ hs0 = hs1)), (1r ` c0)‚àà c1, (0 ` c0)‚àà c1, (1r ` c0)‚â†(0 ` c0))
  adantr(c0 ‚àà Ring, (1r ` c0)‚â†(0 ` c0), (1r ` c0)‚àà c1)
  ringidcl(c0, (1r ` c0), c1)
  adantr(c0 ‚àà Ring, (1r ` c0)‚â†(0 ` c0), (0 ` c0)‚àà c1)
  ring0cl(c0, (0 ` c0), c1)
  simpr(c0 ‚àà Ring, (1r ` c0)‚â†(0 ` c0))
  rspc2ev(hs0, hs1, (1r ` c0), c1, (0 ` c0), c1, (1r ` c0)‚â†(0 ` c0), ¬¨ hs0 = hs1, (1r ` c0)‚â† hs1)

  necon3bd((1r ` c0), (0 ` c0), (c0 ‚àà Ring ‚àß(hs0 ‚àà c1 ‚àß hs1 ‚àà c1)), hs0 = hs1)
  3expb(c0 ‚àà Ring, hs0 ‚àà c1, hs1 ‚àà c1, ((1r ` c0)=(0 ` c0)‚Üí hs0 = hs1))

  fvexi(c1, cbs, c0)

  bitr4i(1o[‚â∫]c1, 2o[‚âº]c1, suc(1o)[‚âº]c1)

  bitri(wcel(c0, cnzr), wa(wcel(c0, crg), wbr(nat1, clt, cfv(chash, c1))), wa(wcel(c0, crg), wne(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))))

  xrltletrd(nat1, cfv(chash, c1), cfv(chash, cpr(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))), wa(wa(wcel(cfv(cur, c0), c1), wcel(cfv(c0g, c0), c1)), wne(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))))
  a1i(wa(wa(wcel(cfv(cur, c0), c1), wcel(cfv(c0g, c0), c1)), wne(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))), wcel(nat1, cxr))

  prex(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))

  mp1i(wa(wa(wcel(cfv(cur, c0), c1), wcel(cfv(c0g, c0), c1)), wne(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))), wcel(cfv(chash, c1), cxr), wcel(c1, universe))
  hashxrcl(c1, universe)
  syl5breqr(nat1, clt, cfv(chash, cpr(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))), nat2, wa(wa(wcel(cfv(cur, c0), c1), wcel(cfv(c0g, c0), c1)), wne(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))))
  1lt2()
  biimpa(wa(wcel(cfv(cur, c0), c1), wcel(cfv(c0g, c0), c1)), wne(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0)), wceq(cfv(chash, cpr(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))), nat2))
  hashprg(cfv(cur, c0), c1, cfv(c0g, c0), c1)
  sylancr(wa(wa(wcel(cfv(cur, c0), c1), wcel(cfv(c0g, c0), c1)), wne(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))), wbr(cfv(chash, cpr(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))), cle, cfv(chash, c1)), wcel(c1, universe), wss(cpr(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0)), c1))
  fvexi(c1, cbs, c0)
  sylib(wa(wa(wcel(cfv(cur, c0), c1), wcel(cfv(c0g, c0), c1)), wne(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0))), wss(cpr(cfv(cur, c0), cfv(c0g, c0)), c1), wa(wcel(cfv(cur, c0), c1), wcel(cfv(c0g, c0), c1)))

blocks.name: opprnzr
blocks.content: The opposite of a nonzero ring is nonzero. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 17-Jun-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm opprnzr(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cnzr), wcel(c1, cnzr))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(coppr, c0))
} = {
  sylanbrc(wcel(c0, cnzr), wcel(c1, cnzr), wcel(c1, crg), wbr(c2o, cdom, cfv(cbs, c0)))
  syl(wcel(c0, cnzr), wcel(c1, crg), wcel(c0, crg))
  nzrring(c0)
  opprring(c0, c1)

blocks.name: 0ring
blocks.content: If a ring has only one element, it is the zero ring. According to Wikipedia ("Zero ring", 14-Apr-2019, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_ring): "The zero ring, denoted {0} or simply 0, consists of the one-element set {0} with the operations + and * defined so that 0 + 0 = 0 and 0 * 0 = 0.". (Contributed by AV, 14-Apr-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm 0ring(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, crg), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1)), wceq(c1, csn(c2)))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cbs, c0))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(c0g, c0))
} = {
  imp(wcel(c0, crg), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(c1, csn(c2)))
  syl(wcel(c0, crg), wi(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(c1, csn(c2))), wcel(c2, c1))
  ring0cl(c0, c2, c1)
  syl5bi(wcel(c2, c1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(c1, csn(c2)), wbr(c1, cen, c1o))
  ax-mp(wb(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wbr(c1, cen, c1o)), wcel(c1, universe))
  fvexi(c1, cbs, c0)
  hashen1(c1, universe)
  ex(wcel(c2, c1), wbr(c1, cen, c1o), wceq(c1, csn(c2)))
  en1eqsn(c2, c1)
}

  ‚ä¢ ((c0 ‚àà Ring ‚àß(# ` c1)= 1)‚Üí c1 = { c2 })
  ‚ä£ c1 =(Base ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c2 =(0 ` c0)
} = {
  imp(c0 ‚àà Ring, (# ` c1)= 1, c1 = { c2 })
  syl(c0 ‚àà Ring, ((# ` c1)= 1 ‚Üí c1 = { c2 }), c2 ‚àà c1)
  ring0cl(c0, c2, c1)
  syl5bi(c2 ‚àà c1, (# ` c1)= 1, c1 = { c2 }, c1[‚âÖ]1o)
  ax-mp(((# ` c1)= 1 ‚Üî c1[‚âÖ]1o), c1 ‚àà ùïå)
  fvexi(c1, cbs, c0)
  hashen1(c1, universe)
  ex(c2 ‚àà c1, c1[‚âÖ]1o, c1 = { c2 })

}

blocks.content: In a ring with only one element, i.e. a zero ring, the zero and the identity element are the same. (Contributed by AV, 14-Apr-2019.)

thm 0ring01eq(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, crg), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1)), wceq(c2, c3))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cbs, c0))

  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cur, c0))
} = {
  mpd(wa(wcel(c0, crg), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1)), wceq(c2, c3), wceq(c1, csn(c2)))

  syl5com(wcel(c0, crg), wceq(c1, csn(c2)), wceq(c2, c3), wcel(c3, c1))
  ringidcl(c0, c3, c1)
  syl6bi(wceq(c1, csn(c2)), wcel(c3, c1), wceq(c2, c3), wcel(c3, csn(c2)))

  eqcomd(c2, c3, wcel(c3, csn(c2)))
  elsni(c3, c2)
}

blocks.name: ring1zr
blocks.content: The only (unital) ring with a base set consisting of one element is the zero ring (at least if its operations are internal binary operations). Note: The assumption ` R e. Ring ` could be weakened if a definition of a non-unital ring ("Rng") was available (it would be sufficient that the multiplication is closed). (Contributed by FL, 13-Feb-2010.) (Revised by AV, 25-Jan-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 7-Feb-2020.)
